{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient is a 6-month-old boy with recurrent vomiting and polyuria. The laboratory tests show elevated PTH levels (140 pg/ml) which are significantly higher than the normal value. This suggests that there is an underlying condition causing hyperparathyroidism. The presence of bilateral nephrocalcinosis on ultrasound abdomen also supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the reduced daily urinary calcium excretion does not fit with the expected picture in Bartter syndrome. Therefore, it is likely that the patient has a primary disorder of the parathyroid gland.", "answer_choice": "D"}
